reviewText: First of all, this DVD is not for Genesis fans and Phil Collins specified it in the booklet. His career was pretty wide in musical creation and this DVD is a gift given for fans of Collins solo career. If you prefer Genesis songs and you would like to enjoy a real good Genesis concert, get "The way we walk" concert DVD or "Live in Wembley".This one offers a great retrospective of Phil Collins best songs from his beginning as a solo artist to his recent album. Everything is there ! His live performance is stunning considering he his half deaf. The band on the stage is incredible with a dozen of musicians. Visual effects are pretty good too.Daryl S., the guitarist, offers very good guitar solos and Chester T., the second drummer, has good respect for Collins interpretations on percussions. Sound recording as well as filming are both nearly perfect.My only complain is about the featurettes, boring I think. But Collins isn't a cheap guy, he personally supervised the production of the concert film on DVD. Generous, he provides us with all the videos from the songs on the concert setlist in addition to the Live Aid performance of "Agains all odds" and a few other extras.Overall, hours of great Phil Collins plus a photo gallery and wonderful live show !

reviewText: I am a huge Phil Collins fan. I have lots of his music and DVD's. I recently purchased his "Finally...The First Farewell Tour" DVD and I was a little disappointed. As I tried to figure out why I was not totally satisfied with this DVD, I realized it was simply because I have seen the "Live and Loose in Paris" DVD that Phil Collins released in 1997. Although both DVD's feature many of the same great tunes, the Live and Loose is much more energetic than Finally. The circular stage on the Live and Loose DVD will give you much more exposure to the explosive energy Phil Collins and his band are capable of delivering. You are certain to enjoy this DVD, but if you don't already own Live and Loose in Paris, buy it before you buy this one. You won't be sorry.
summary: Grest - but not the best Phil has to offer

reviewText: Phil Collins is superb.  Recorded live in Paris in HD.  This is a DVD / HD transfer - as close to HD as you can get without being HD.  If you have an HDTV you will surely enjoy this concert and the DTS soundtrack along with it.  All the songs are here and the audience is into it.  I believe it deserves a 5 star rating - but I don't like all the flashy multi-colored lighting behind the band.  It's kind of a distraction - well actually it is a distraction.  Much better with the blue / black background lighting - the true colors appear more realistic.  The light show was someones foolish idea - no doubt - reminds me of the flashy light show in the background for the Elton John live DVD - One Night Only - but I expect that from him.  Buy this if you like Phil Collins - you will not be dissapointed - a must have.....
summary: It doesn't get any better than this from Phil Collins...

reviewText: Simply put, this is a great concert DVD.  The concert itself is great in terms of lighting, sound and song selection.  Most Phil Collins fans can probably name a few omitted songs they would like to have seen included, but overall the song choices are an excellent overview of Collins' solo career.  The extras alone are worth the purchase price of the collection.  The bonus features include a decent, if incomplete, collection of Collin's videos, some live footage of previous performances, a network special to promote the "But Seriously" album, and an amusing sketch in which Collins introduces the "behind the scenes" staff of the concert tour (it's neat that Collins goes to this length to salute these staffers).  These extras sold me on a concert video I wasn't sure about purchasing. All in all, this concert video is a great value that will appeal to even casual fans of Phil Collins' solo work.One technical note, in reply to another reviewer - the pause feature doesn't work on my DVD player either (I also have a Sony player), and unless I'm missing something, neither do the "extra angles" featured on some of the songs. And like that reviewer, this is the first time I've encountered this.  A relatively minor incovenience - just thought I'd reply to the earlier comments.

reviewText: So, Finally it's here, the 5th official live video release from Phil's 6th worldtour as a solo artist (previous releases count the Passadena 1982 video, the Dallas 1985 video, the Berlin 1990 video/2DVD, and the Paris 1997 video/DVD). As such, one cannot quite keep from comparing this release to these former releases, when one wants to make an evaluation of the DVD. This being said, I shall emphasize that if your relatively new into Phil's music, or simply haven't bought the older releases for one reason or another, this is an excellent show, featuring a wide range of his greatest and best loved hits, and giving a very fine overview of how Phil is on stage. Furthermore, you'll have a large amount of extra features thrown in as an added value.- THE TRACK LISTING -Perhaps the greatest pro of this release is, that it features the FULL concert. A full 24 tracks are we treated with, which can only be described as generous. The only other complete release so far was the 1990 Serious Hits In Berlin (re-released in 2xDVD last year), and it is always a great frustration to the fans, when one of their favorite songs are cut away in the editing.Furthermore, the set-list of this tour is quite well-balanced, featuring practically all the greatest, old as well as new - In The Air Tonight, Susudio, One More Night, Dance Into The Light, Another Day In Paradise, Can't Hurry Love, Can't Stop Loving You, and I could go on and on. Of course, a few tracks that I'd love to have seen here are missing - not one track from the Both Sides album - according to Phil his best, and I agree - is included, the title track would have fitted in perfectly; his most recent hit-single from the Brother Bear soundtrack, Look Through My Eyes, is omitted, this soundtrack being represented instead by the ballad No Way Out - which is in fact not a bad treat. I should have loved to have had the piano version of Do You Remember?, as performed on the '97 tour, but of course the line has to be drawn somewhere.Instead, we are treated with several very pleasant surprises: An absolutely amazing gospel-version of True Colours, far superior to his '98 remake; a lovely version of Come With Me from his recent Testify album, again drawing on his amazing 5-piece of back-up vocalists; an impressive rendition of the gospel-like No Way Out, again using the full power of this vocal potential; and nearly last but not least, another track from the Testify album, It's Not Too Late, another of my favorites, and again presented in a wonderfull new version.- THE PERFORMANCE -The performance is, overall, great without being superb. Phil is in good vocal shape, but not as amazing as on the Live And Loose In Paris release from '97. The musicians play amazing, and overall this will probably rank second - after the 97 Paris concert, that was probably Phil's best ever - amongst his live releases. The arrangement is excellent, the upbeat songs are perfomed spotlessly, and the real power of the shw comes with the amazing vocal arrangement on several of the ballads, as mentioned above - True Colours, Come With Me, No Way Out and It's Not Too Late.Generally, the on-scene performance is pretty dynamic and goes well along with the music - still, the scene doesn't quite give the same space for playing and entertainment as did the circular in-the-round stage used on the '97 tour. The lighting is ok, but I was not impressed - again, comparing with the amazing work on the '97 show, this was a minor let-down.- SOUND AND FILMING -The sound is virtually perfect, at least I can't find anything to complain on here. The sound of the music is much more pleasant than on the Berlin '90 show, which was perhaps the greatest weeknes of that show in my oppinion. The filming is excellent as well, the picture quality is great, and I don't miss the multi-camera angles option, which is even included on a few tracks.- EXTRA FEATURES -All the videos for the featured songs are included - a generous treat for the fans. Ok, most of the videos are quite mediocre, but still, Phil could've released a seperate video-DVD and ripped the fans of another 20 . Of course, this is no guarantee that such a release will not come, as the videos of songs not played in the concert are not included. Of course, that should've been nice ... we're talking another 5 or 10 videos here I think.Some old live-footage is included here, but frankly, this is nothing to go for. The Live Aid Against All Odds performance and the Secret Policeman's Ball In The Air Tonight performance are both in pretty lousy quality, mainly of interest for the serious fans. The 'wild card' features a 20-minutes performance with the Big Band, which never was my taste, so I can hardly appreciate this piece. Instead, there are loads of rare footage not included, that would've been obvious to include: The fantastic Policeman's Ball performance of The Roof Is Leaking, the very rare 1997 performance of The Same Moon with Laura Pausini (not sure whether this was a radio or TV show, this might not have been filmed), the 2002 TV performance of Wake Up Call, and I could go on. Perhaps one day, on future releases, these gems will se the light of day.Still, these features, and also several documentaries, TV-specials and a gallery, are much more that what've been included on earlier releases, and with a full 224 minutes of extra material (yes, that's nealy 4 hours!), and a 133 minutes live-show, this can only be described as an extremely generous release, and defenitely woth bying, die-hard fan or newcommer.Overall Rating: 9/10
summary: A great release, even if I have a few objections.

reviewText: The Fist Farewell Tour DVD is easily the best DVD released by Phil Collins to date. Firstly the performance is first rate with Phil's voice sounding better than ever and with Chester Thomson back on drums the music too has lifted a notch. The quality of the sound is astounding and the director did a great job with the way in which this production was filmed, with no jumping between shots at a rapid rate as can be seen on some other concert dvd's. The amount of extra's are generous to say the least with almost every song performed in concert being accompanied by its video in the extra's. Most other artists would hold this material over for another dvd, so anyone who says this isn't value for money needs a reality check. All this ensures this is a dvd that will be enjoyed for years to come.
summary: The Ultimate Phil Collins DVD So Far.

reviewText: There is no doubt about Phil Collins this past year. He has had a marvelous revival of his work with his days performing as a part of Genesis. Not only did he perform for the first time with them in 15 years, but the sound of Phil, Mike Rutherford and Tony Banks sounded even better than ever. Especially with their catalog being fully restored past and present. That feeling has also been a bit sad for his solo efforts though. He just embattled a tough divorce, and his work with the recent Broadway musical version of Disney's Tarzan hasn't didn't really deliver to those fans that still want Phil to be n their hearts. But, that alone may be as it was, there are still many fans who want him to return to touring on his own. That is shown strong from his last tour back in 2004.Phil Collins recent concert DVD, Finally: The First Farewell Tour is a 2 disc DVD that reflected highlights from an dynamic concert in Paris he performed, promoting for his 2002 album, Testify. Phil's performance was assertive, and brought out a lot of fun and excitement from his classics including Against All Odds, Take Me Home, and the fun fulfilled Something Happened On The Way To Heaven. The songs sound great, but the concert alone isn't enough here to tide Phil Collins fans alone. The DVD set includes a lot of extras, including music videos for his biggest hits including A Groovy Kind Of Love, Don't Lose My Number, as well as some of his lesser-known songs like Hang In Long Enough, Dance Into The Light, and his cover of Cyndi Lauper's True Colors. The extras bring in a lot more appeal that works well not just in the price, but as a great glimpse at how humorous and eclectic Phil has been over the years.All in al, while there have been so many music video DVD's that have lacked heart, and haven't delivered the effort within their price, it is nice to know that Phil Collins is still serious enough to hit a home run with this concert. My one gripe is that I wish Phil could've performed some of other great songs like Everyday, I Wish It Would Rain Down and Don't Let Him Steal Your Heart Away. Nevertheless, this is still a remarkable reintroduction to one of the most serious artists to have ever come out of the 80's. Phil Collins' Finally: The First Farewell Tour is one of the best live concert DVD's I really think is a great addition to your DVD library.Price: B+Remastering: A-Extras: A-Concert: B 1/2+Overall: B+

reviewText: Phil Collins' horn-powered group is tight and professional, and this 2-DVD set is an excellent value. Not only do you get a complete concert with surround sound and widescreen video, but you also get an 80% complete collection of Phil's videos and also a documentary. Unfortunately, the video clips must be accessed individually, and there isn't a way to watch the videos play as a continuous program.Collins is backed by mostly the same instrument players who were heard on "Live and Loose in Paris", excepting that Bassist Leland Sklar returns, replacing Nathan East.The set list focuses on the popular "No Jacket Required","But Seriously" & "Dance Into The Light" albums, though the few subsequent songs included cause the pace to briefly drag.Collins seldom has adequate on-stage duet partners to re-create the Marylin Martins part on "Separate Lives" &  the Philip Bailey part on "Easy Lover", and this show is no exception. On "Separate Lives", Collins(in this show) has a throaty,low-pitched, masculine-sounding African American woman to duet with, and while she's a skillful singer, she takes too many melodic and phrasing liberties with "Separate Lives". This lady, and a male background vocalist take turns trying to replace Philip Bailey on "Easy Lover", but Bailey's high falsetto notes are simply out of these singers' ranges, and they have no option but to sing the song quite differently. This is one area where Nathan East is missed. He could easily reproduce the Philip Bailey part, and with good reason:East co-wrote "Easy Lover".There are very occasional moments during this show, where Collins' very highest notes sound slightly thinner or more nasal than in the past. Collins hits all the required notes(though in a few instances avoiding holding them for as long), but from the way Collins occasionally grimaces in the first half of the show, it is obvious that it is not as effortless to reach these high notes in his mid-50's as it was in his mid-30's.(in a subsequent Genesis reunion tour, Collins dropped the keys of most of the songs, de-tuning the songs as much as 3 keys)Don't get me wrong, this is a generally excellent, well performed,recorded and filmed show, and the two-disc set is value packed, but if you don't have a Phil Collins DVD yet, I'd advise you to start with "Live and Loose in Paris", then buy this set. This is a fine farewell from Collins. It's good to quit at the top.
Title: N/A

reviewText: While this dvd is packed with extras, the concert is the only thing I have a problem with.The performance is good, but not the best.  His past concert videos display much better energy and rawness...The problem is with the set list itself.It's pretty much a "greatest hits" album done live..and didn't we have this in 1991 with his album "Serious hits live"??I would have liked to have heard some lesser-played album cuts in the set like "thru these walls", "Inside out", "I cannot believe it's true", "Don't let him steal your heart away".Why does Phil think people just want the obvious, over-played "HITS"?(the same thing happened with the recent Genesis tour--too many hits--but that's another review..lol)Ironically, the best thing on the entire DVD is the "wild card", which is a 20-minute SIZZLING performance of AWB's "Pick up the pieces" with 5 stellar sax players--PUTTING IT DOWN! as well as George Duke on piano..who churns out an amazing solo as well.The dvd is worth it for this performance and the videos, but not so much for the concert.ReenoKing of Electrofunk
summary: WORTH THE MONEY--LOTS OF CONTENT HERE

reviewText: I would give Phil's newest dual-disc DVD ten stars if I could.  The concert is amazing and begins with ten minutes of pure DRUMS!  The setlist is incredible, but Phil has so many wonderful songs that this concert (recorded in Paris, back in June of '04) could've been--should've been--four hours long, in an effort to get in every good song, but two hours and fifteen minutes isn't too bad.  If Phil's voice and physical energy would've held out, he and his awesome band could've performed 40-50 songs and nobody in that Paris audience would've batted an eye.Two times during the concert Phil announced that this tour (2003-2004) will unfortunately be the last one and he received mixed reactions from the audience--cheering and booing.For the past nearly forty years, Phil has worked hard in the music business (by himself, with Genesis and with "Brand X", along with his Big Band era), so he deserves to be able to retire while still at the top of his success.  Besides, back in December, his (third) wife Orianne gave him a new son, so the current generation of his family has become more important to him than fame and fortune.This new dual-disc DVD also offers incredible bonus material, including music videos.If you love Phil Collins, do not hesitate any longer--get a copy of this DVD!  I got mine yesterday at the nearest Barnes & Noble."Finally...The First Farewell" is an experience to be cherished and is a DVD that is worth every cent of its purchase price.
summary: The BEST music-concert DVD that has ever been made!

reviewText: I'm not a huge fan, but the concert was generally enjoyable with a couple of songs being outstanding primarily due to the energy of everyone on stage. Some of the staging, while flamboyant and well-used, looked a bit contrived.I share the irritation on the audio that others have mentioned. IT does not afflict every song but on a few songs it sounds like a drunk monkey was bouncing around with the levels constantly. It is incredibly annoying. I can't imagine why the producers would release the DVD with that low level of consistent quality.If you want to see what a top notch music DVD looks and SOUNDS like, see Springsteen in Barcelona. The staging is much simpler with Springsteen but the DVD production values are excellent.
summary: Pretty good but ditto the inconsistent audio
